    Positional Analogue Scanning: An Effective Strategy for Multiparameter Optimization in Drug Design

    • Lewis D. Pennington*
      Lewis D. Pennington
      Medicinal Chemistry, Alkermes, Inc., 852 Winter Street, Waltham, Massachusetts 02451-1420, United States
      *L.D.P.: phone, +1-781-609-6868; email, [email protected]

    SUBJECTS:
    • Drug discovery,

    • Stability
    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Minimizing the number and duration of design cycles needed to optimize hit or lead compounds into high-quality chemical probes or drug candidates is an ongoing challenge in biomedical research. Small structure modifications to hit or lead compounds can have meaningful impacts on pharmacological profiles due to significant effects on molecular and physicochemical properties and intra- and intermolecular interactions. Rapid pharmacological profiling of an efficiently prepared series of positional analogues stemming from the systematic exchange of methine groups with heteroatoms or other substituents in aromatic or heteroaromatic ring-containing hit or lead compounds is one approach toward minimizing design cycles (e.g., exchange of aromatic or heteroaromatic CH groups with N atoms or CF, CMe, or COH groups). In this Perspective, positional analogue scanning is shown to be an effective strategy for multiparameter optimization in drug design, whereby substantial improvements in a variety of pharmacological parameters can be achieved.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Minimizing the number and duration of design cycles needed to optimize hit or lead compounds into high-quality chemical probes or drug candidates remains a challenge for biomedical research.(1,2) Following the seminal statistical analysis of the potency effects of common structure modifications by Hajduk and Sauer 12 years ago,(3) it has become increasingly appreciated that minor structure modifications to hit or lead compounds can have meaningful impacts on pharmacological profiles due to significant effects on molecular and physicochemical properties and intra- and intermolecular interactions.(4−6) Despite numerous advances in structural biology and computational chemistry over the past 30 years,(7) the complexity of biological systems and the variability of bioassay data continue to complicate computational predictions of the impacts of small structure modifications on multiple pharmacological parameters.(8) For example, having structural information at atomic resolution not only for the desired target but also for multiple antitargets as well as having predictive models for all relevant optimization parameters is still impracticable for many drug discovery programs.
    Brown and co-workers recently suggested that one way to identify better hit compounds is by having more balanced distributions of positional analogues in corporate compound collections and improving the use of multiparameter decision trees and statistics.(9) Similarly, rapid pharmacological profiling of an efficiently prepared series of positional analogues stemming from the systematic exchange of methine groups with heteroatoms or other substituents in aromatic or heteroaromatic ring-containing hit or lead compounds can be an effective strategy for multiparameter optimization (Figure 1). This approach, termed positional analogue scanning in this Perspective, leverages the beneficial effects that minor structure modifications can have on molecular and physicochemical properties and intra- and intermolecular interactions,(4−6) which can lead to substantial improvements in a variety of pharmacological parameters to streamline multiparameter optimization efforts.(10) Surprisingly, despite myriad manifestations of positional analogue scanning being reported in the medicinal chemistry literature for decades, no review has been published to inspire and guide the effective use of this strategy for multiparameter optimization in drug design.
    Positional analogue scanning for multiparameter optimization of aromatic or heteroaromatic ring-containing hit or lead compounds is distinct from the Topliss method for potency optimization of aromatic ring-containing hit or lead compounds (Figure 2).(11) The method of Topliss is a systematic approach for iteratively selecting ring substituents and analyzing structure–activity relationships (SARs) resulting from the properties and patterns of ring substituents, which considers the effects of ring substituents on hydrophobic (π), electronic (σ), and steric (Es) parameters developed by Hansch.(12) Positional analogue scanning leverages the beneficial effects that minor structure modifications can have on molecular and physicochemical properties such as molecular weight (MW), hydrogen bond donors (HBDs), hydrogen bond acceptors (HBAs), polar surface area (PSA), acidity/basicity (pKa), lipophilicity (log P and log DpH), and aqueous solubility (SH2O), as well as intra- and intermolecular interactions that can affect ligand conformation and receptor binding. Positional analogue scanning is intended to optimize pharmacological parameters such as binding affinity and kinetics, functional activity and potency, target selectivity, passive permeability, active transport, protein binding, metabolic stability, pharmacokinetics, and safety. Positional analogue scanning is ideally suited for simultaneous multiparameter optimization and sophisticated data analysis.
    Various manifestations of positional analogue scanning have been reported in the literature for decades, variably described as an atom or substituent scan, transposition, shift, walk, dance, or shuffle, generally constituting a partial scan of a single aromatic or heteroaromatic ring of a polycyclic drug molecule, and typically focused on a single pharmacological parameter, such as potency.(13,14) It is recommended in this Perspective that a generic term, positional analogue scanning, be used to describe this general strategy, as positional analogue scanning in small molecule drug discovery is analogous to alanine scanning in polypeptide biochemical studies and both are intended to be systematic and complete.(15,16) The maximal value of positional analogue scanning can be realized by assessment of negative, neutral, or positive impacts across multiple pharmacological parameters, exploring all possible positional analogues in situations where predictive modeling is not available.(9,17) Additionally, positional analogue scanning can provide opportunities to identify activity cliffs and nonadditive SAR that may elucidate ligand binding conformations and receptor binding modes.(18) The modern need in chemical biology and drug discovery for rapid and simultaneous multiparameter optimization justifies the synthesis investment that may be required to enable full positional analogue scanning.
    An example of full, iterative nitrogen scanning is shown in Figure 3.(19) As part of a program seeking selective agonists of the class A GPCR sphingosine-1-phosphate-1 receptor (S1P1), early lead compound 1 was identified. Though 1 displays moderate potency toward S1P1 and good stability in rat liver microsomes (S1P1 EC50, Emax = 70 nM, 110%; RLM CLint < 14 μL min–1 mg–1), it also exhibits undesired activity against S1P3 (S1P3 EC50, Emax = 1.5 μM, 92%), low solubility in aqueous media (SpH 7.4, PBS < 1.0 μg/mL), and poor cell permeability (LLC-PK1 Papp A → B, ER = 1.2 × 10–6 cm/s, 0.40). In the absence of X-ray crystal structures and predictive models for S1P1 and S1P3, nitrogen scanning of 1 was undertaken to probe impacts on potency and selectivity and to tune molecular and physicochemical properties with minimal effect on molecular weight. Of the 11 monoaza-analogues of 1 prepared and tested (2–12), only positional analogues 2, 5, 8, 10, and 11 displayed similar or improved physicochemical and pharmacological properties compared to 1 (Figure 3). When 1 or positional analogue 2, 5, 8, 10, or 11 was dosed orally in female Lewis rats in a single-dose screening assay (1.0 mg/kg), only positional analogue 10 achieved an unbound plasma concentration sufficient to elicit reduction of peripheral lymphocyte count (Cu,plasma = 66 nM; PLC POC = −64%). A second iteration of nitrogen scanning, combining the favored positional analogue 10 in ring system C/C′ with the favored positional analogue 2 or 5 in ring system A or B, respectively, sought potentially additive benefits of multiple nitrogen atoms. This effort resulted in the identification of diaza-analogue 13, which compared to 1 exhibits improved potency toward S1P1 and selectivity against S1P3 (S1P1 EC50, Emax = 20 nM, 120%; S1P3 EC50, Emax = inactive), enhanced solubility in aqueous media (SpH 7.4, PBS = 2.4 μg/mL), and better cell permeability (LLC-PK1 Papp A → B, ER = 6.7 × 10–6 cm/s, 1.0) while maintaining good stability in rat liver microsomes (RLM CLint < 14 μL min–1 mg–1). When 13 was dosed orally in female Lewis rats in a single-dose screening assay (1.0 mg/kg), it elicited reduction of peripheral lymphocyte count at a lower unbound plasma concentration versus 10 (Cu,plasma = 6.1 nM; PLC POC = −64%). It is interesting to note the observation of numerous activity cliffs in transforming 1 to monoaza-analogues 2–12 (Figure 3), as well as unfavorable nonadditive SAR when combining positional analogues 2 and 10 to give the corresponding diaza-analogue (not shown; S1P1 EC50 = 70, 60, 24, and 200 nM, for 1, 2, 10, and the corresponding diaza-analogue, respectively). It is also worth noting that the observed impacts on solubility, permeability, and metabolic stability upon positional analogue scanning do not correlate with changes in cLogP. While the probabilistic analyses and predictions discussed below will help to guide positional analogue scanning, this example illustrates the value of full rather than partial positional analogue scanning to maximize the chances of success.
    An example of partial, tandem fluorine and nitrogen scanning is illustrated in Figure 4.(20) In a program searching for dual inhibitors of rapidly accelerated fibrosarcoma kinase (Raf) and mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase (MEK), lead compound 14 was discovered. Compound 14 exhibits modest potency toward C-Raf and MEK1 (C-Raf and MEK1 IC50 = 530 and 230 nM, respectively), moderate solubility in fasted-state simulated intestinal fluid (SFaSSIF = 32 μg/mL), favorable parallel artificial membrane permeability (PAMPA Papp = 6.0 × 10–6 cm/s), and good stability in human liver microsomes (HLM CLint = 6.0 μL min–1 mg–1). To exploit the unique properties of fluorine in drug-like molecules,(5c) fluorine scanning of 14 was undertaken to probe impacts on potency while minimizing effects on molecular and physicochemical properties. Of the five monofluoro-analogues of 14 that were synthetically accessible by nonselective late-stage fluorination (15–19), positional analogue 17 displays the best balance of physicochemical and pharmacological properties (Figure 4). To capitalize on the favorable properties often imparted by aromatic nitrogen atoms in drug-like molecules,(4a,b) a parallel nitrogen scanning effort on an N-methyl derivative of 14 (20) was initiated to interrogate impacts on potency and to tune molecular and physicochemical properties. Of the four monoaza-analogues of 20 that were readily synthetically accessible (21–24), positional analogue 24 exhibits the best balance of physicochemical and pharmacological properties (Figure 4). Compound 25 arose from combining the favored positional analogues 17 and 24 from the fluorine and nitrogen scanning efforts, respectively, and exchanging the metabolically labile N,N-dimethylcarbamate group with the more stable 2-pyrimidinyl ring. Compound 25 displays favorable potency toward C-Raf and MEK1 (C-Raf and MEK1 IC50 = 56 and 160 nM, respectively), good solubility in fasted-state simulated intestinal fluid (SFaSSIF = 160 μg/mL), and excellent stability in human liver microsomes (HLM CLint = 0.50 μL min–1 mg–1), as well as no inhibition of cytochrome P450 3A4 (CYP 3A4 IC50 > 100 μM). Compound 25 was advanced into clinical trials. As with the case study summarized in Figure 3, several activity cliffs were observed in converting 14 to monofluoro-analogues 15–19 and 20 to monoaza-analogues 21–24 (Figure 4).
    Although positional analogue scanning can be rendered more efficient today than 30 years ago by exploiting numerous advances in chemical synthesis and building block availability,(21,22) more progress is needed.(23) Positional analogue scanning for the case studies in this Perspective generally relied on de novo syntheses of each positional analogue using common intermediates and commercially available building blocks; thus the syntheses for the CH group progenitors and their positional analogues were usually similar in length and yield. Positional analogue scanning could be made even more efficient by late-stage functionalization of the CH progenitors to afford all positional analogues either simultaneously or in parallel. Recent advances in CH group activation, photoredox catalysis, electrochemistry, and biotransformation offer the potential to increase the efficiency of fluorine, methyl, and hydroxyl scanning.(20a,24) Numerous synthetic methods to introduce fluorine atoms, methyl groups, or hydroxyl groups on aromatic and heteroaromatic ring systems in pharmaceutical and agrochemical compounds have been reported.(5a,25−27) While a limited number of synthetic methods allow direct, nonselective CH functionalization to prepare multiple positional analogues simultaneously at late-stages of synthesis,(20a) most synthetic methods aim to provide selectively a single positional analogue. An increased variety of commercially available building blocks would be a particularly important advancement for nitrogen scanning.(19a,21) Recent advances in Minisci-type reactions may facilitate the synthesis of functionalized aza-heteroaromatic building blocks that could be used for de novo syntheses of positional analogues for nitrogen scanning.(28)
    For this Perspective, comprehensive matched molecular pair (MMP) and positional analogue analyses were performed to provide probabilistic expectations and further substantiation that small structure modifications to hit or lead compounds can have meaningful impacts on a variety of pharmacological parameters.(4−6,9,17,18) Additionally, several case studies of positional analogue scanning published over the past 12 years have been highlighted to demonstrate the effectiveness of this strategy for multiparameter optimization in drug design. Because Young and Leeson recently suggested four structure modifications (the exchange of CH groups with N atoms or CF, CMe, or COH groups) as privileged transformations for multiparameter optimization,(6b) these structure modifications were selected to be represented in the MMP and positional analogue analyses, as well as the case studies; however, other common structure modifications are also amenable to positional analogue scanning (e.g., exchange of CH groups with CCN, CCl, CCF3, or COMe groups).(5d,9) These structure modifications effectively scan molecular and physicochemical property space: N atoms and CCN groups add polarity and HBAs, CF and CCl groups increase van der Waals radii, CMe and CCF3 groups increase lipophilicity, and COH and COMe groups add polarity and HBDs and/or HBAs. These structure modifications may also impart beneficial or informative conformational effects. It should be noted that in contrast to the two case studies discussed above that embody the full spectrum of partial, full, iterative, and/or tandem positional analogue scanning with broad pharmacological profiling, many of the case studies detailed below exemplify targeted positional analogue scanning on selected rings with narrow pharmacological profiling, as is common in the biomedical research literature.
    Most of the case studies of positional analogue scanning described below were executed during late-stages of multiparameter optimization; however, positional analogue scanning can also have meaningful impacts during early stages of multiparameter optimization. When structure-based drug design is not an option due to a lack of structural information for the desired target and key antitargets and a lack of predictive models for the parameters that need to be optimized, positional analogue scanning can be considered as a systematic version of scaffold-hopping and focused library design for multiparameter optimization. On the other hand, if target structures are available, binding and functional activity parameters can be predicted using small molecule docking and scoring approaches(29) or more sophisticated approaches to calculate binding free energies such as free energy perturbation (FEP). In fact, the appendage of methyl groups has been exhaustively studied using FEP.(5b) Additionally, combinations of MMPs and quantitative structure–activity relationship (QSAR) models have been explored to aid the optimization process.(30) Another concept employed in hit-to-lead optimization couples virtual screening with focused library design and diversity-oriented synthesis.(31) These computer-aided optimization methods, including docking, FEP, QSAR, and diversity approaches, focus mostly on improving binding free energies, paying less attention to multiparameter optimization challenges. In the following Discussion section, we provide MMP analyses of 13 parameters relevant to drug design. It is hoped that the statistical analyses presented here may afford quantitative guidance on how positional analogue scanning can impact multiple pharmacological parameters. Finally, we also present several case studies of how positional analogue scanning has been leveraged to overcome multiparameter optimization challenges for the identification of advanced leads, preclinical candidates, and clinical candidates, which may serve to inspire and guide the effective use of this strategy in drug design.

    Discussion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    MMP Analyses

    As an initial step toward providing probabilistic expectations for the impacts of positional analogue scanning on a variety of pharmacological parameters, comprehensive MMP analyses were performed on ChEMBL24 data,(32) focusing on exchanges of aromatic and heteroaromatic CH groups with N atoms or CF, CMe, or COH groups (Figure 5). These MMP analyses were extracted from ∼1.8 million compounds with ∼15 million activity data from more than 1.0 million assays stored in the ChEMBL database. Assays included in the MMP analyses were selected either by assay type (e.g., “B” for binding and “F” for functional) or by text-appropriate searches in the assay description field of the ChEMBL database; the MMPs were included for all assay types irrespective of the measure or unit. Because these MMP analyses incorporate high structural diversity for aromatic and heteroaromatic ring systems, it is believed these MMP analyses are the most comprehensive to date for the above four structure modifications, going beyond previously reported MMP analyses for isolated five- and six-membered aromatic and heteroaromatic rings, as well as fluorine-substituted phenyl rings.(9,17)
    The MMP analyses for the four structure modifications and 13 pharmacological parameters are summarized in Figure 5. To aid the visualization and interpretation of the MMP analyses, the statistical data for the impacts of the four structure modifications on each of the pharmacological parameters are presented in three bins: ≥3-fold decreases (blue), <3-fold changes (gray), or ≥3-fold increases (orange). For exact values, see the Supporting Information (Tables S1–S4). The 3-fold threshold for bin assignments was chosen on one hand to maximize the number of instances observed in each bin and on the other hand to ensure the recording of meaningful impacts beyond potential experimental variability.(8a,18a,b) The statistical significances of the differences between the ≥3-fold decreases and ≥3-fold increases have been calculated as χ2p-values and marked in Figure 5. It is important to note that observing ≥3-fold changes is not equally achievable for all pharmacological parameters. Impacts on binding affinity or functional activity are often observed across multiple orders of magnitude, restricted only by the wall of the assay at low concentrations, or perhaps formulation or reagent restrictions at high concentrations. In contrast, measurement ranges for in vitro clearance parameters can be limited to as little as 1.0 order of magnitude due to limited incubation times in microsomal or hepatocyte stability assays, making it much harder to observe a ≥3-fold change.
    The MMP analyses in Figure 5 illustrate how likely it is to see a meaningful impact on a pharmacological parameter of interest. For example, the likelihood of seeing a ≥3-fold change (either increase or decrease) in binding affinity for CH group → N atom exchanges is ∼42%. In addition, Figure 5 illustrates that the chance of observing ≥3-fold decreases in binding affinity for CH group → N atom exchanges is significantly higher than for observing ≥3-fold increases (27% versus 15%, respectively; p-value of <0.001). Several observations provide statistical quantification for general trends that have been widely known. For instance, CH group → N atom or COH group exchanges have a ∼38% probability of significantly increasing solubility ≥3-fold while CH group → CF or CMe group exchanges have an ∼18–23% chance of decreasing solubility ≥3-fold. Other findings may be less expected. For example, the impacts of CH group → CF group exchanges are minimal for microsomal stability, clearance, or half-life, while the impacts are more pronounced for binding affinity and functional activity. Other less expected findings include CH group → COH group exchanges having a 19% chance of increasing cytotoxicity ≥3-fold. In summary, these four structure modifications afford a reasonable chance of having meaningful impacts on a variety of pharmacological parameters commonly encountered during multiparameter optimization.

    Positional Analogue Analyses

    To unmask effects that may rely on specific positional analogues as the next step to providing probabilistic expectations for the impacts of positional analogue scanning on a variety of pharmacological parameters, positional analogue analyses were performed by dissection of the above MMP analyses for individual positional analogues (Figure 6). Positional analogue designations in Figure 6 are assigned relative to the nearest ring substituent or ring fusion; illustrative examples are included in the Supporting Information (Table S8). Because of the wide variety of substitutions contained in each of the three different subsets of positional analogue designations, the differences between the designated subsets may not always be easy to interpret. However, in some cases the positional analogue analysis reveals marked differences that are compelling. For instance, the MMP analyses in Figure 5 for CH group → N atom exchanges suggest the likelihood of ≥3-fold decreases is much greater than the likelihood of ≥3-fold increases in CYP inhibition (33% versus 11%, respectively), even though CH group → N atom exchanges leading to 4-aza-analogues would be expected to result in a greater likelihood for increases in CYP inhibition. This perhaps unexpected observation may be due to the MMP analyses masking positional analogue differences (i.e., 2-aza- versus 3-aza- versus 4-aza-analogues). Figure 6 suggests that this is indeed the case. 2-Aza-analogues from CH group → N atom exchanges exhibit a 40% chance of decreasing CYP inhibition ≥3-fold while 4-aza-analogues afford a 40% chance of increasing CYP inhibition ≥3-fold. Positional analogue dependencies were analyzed for the eight pharmacological parameters for which a sufficient number of MMPs could be extracted from the ChEMBL database. As with the MMP analyses in Figure 5, the positional analogue analyses in Figure 6 reveal both expected and unexpected findings. For instance, the greater likelihood for ≥3-fold increases in CYP inhibition for CH group → N atom exchanges leading to 4-aza-analogues is expected, while the greater likelihood for ≥3-fold decreases in CYP inhibition for CH group → N atom exchanges leading to 2-aza-analogues is perhaps unexpected. Similarly, the greater likelihood for ≥3-fold increases in permeability for CH group → CMe group exchanges leading to 2-methyl-analogues compared to other positional analogues may not be expected.
    Statistical significances for the differences between the likelihood of ≥3-fold decreases and ≥3-fold increases were achieved for 40% of the MMPs in Figure 5 (21/52) and for 43% of the positional analogues in Figure 6 (41/96). Moreover, for almost all parameters in Figures 5 and 6, differences between <3-fold changes and ≥3-fold changes were statistically significant (p-values not shown). Quantifying the probability of observing a change in a parameter is important as it varies greatly between parameters, even if it is unclear whether the result will be an increase or a decrease. While it would have been desirable to obtain MMPs for additional parameters of interest such as plasma protein binding or in vivo toxicity, they were not included in the analyses due to sparseness of data.
    Some additional insight into the positional analogue analyses can be gained from inspecting the different assay subsets included in the pharmacological parameter categories. For example, for the pharmacological parameter of clearance, both in vitro and in vivo assays were included to have sufficient data for a statistically meaningful analysis. Because of the greater likelihood of ≥3-fold decreases in clearance for CH group → CF group exchanges leading to 4-fluoro-analogues, a detailed analysis was undertaken of the rat clearance subset of the clearance data. It was found that 55 of the 218 MMPs are associated with 40 rat clearance studies. It was also found that 10 of the 55 MMPs are associated with ≥3-fold decreases in rat clearance (18%), while no cases were found with ≥3-fold increases in rat clearance. The statistical significance of the preference for ≥3-fold decreases in rat clearance (p-value = 0.002) is slightly stronger than that for all 218 MMPs associated with the clearance analysis for the 4-fluoro-analogues in Figure 6 (p-value = 0.009). The most favorable rat clearance result for 4-fluoro-analogues was found for a MMP of melanin concentrating hormone receptor 1 antagonists.(33) This MMP exhibits a 16-fold decrease in rat clearance along with an equally impressive increase in oral bioavailability (F: 35% → 93%). In contrast, the most unfavorable rat clearance result for 4-fluoro-analogues was observed for a MMP of ghrelin receptor agonists.(34) This MMP displays a 2.6-fold increase in rat clearance. The distribution of fold-changes in rat clearance is available in the Supporting Information (Figure S2).
    The diversity of assay subtypes included for each parameter is tremendous. On average, there are only three MMPs associated with the same assay (see Table S6 in the Supporting Information). For instance, the 19 355 MMPs for CH group → N atom exchanges analyzed for changes in functional activities are associated with 7586 different assays. Combining data from different assays is possible because for each MMP the same assay was used and correlations between different assays are largely irrelevant when fold-differences of MMPs are analyzed. However, some bias is introduced from assays presenting different data ranges that render the measurement of a 3-fold change less or more difficult. For a few parameters, this bias can be particularly restrictive. For instance, for hepatic clearance, due to the upper limits of hepatic blood flow, a 3-fold change can practically be observed only between truly stable and unstable compounds. Because of the nonlinearity with which clearance contributes to the efficacious dose, a lower than 3-fold change would be meaningful to report for this parameter; however, due to the large variability between the tens of thousands of different assays analyzed here, it was decided not to provide assay-customized fold thresholds. While being a practical necessity, it is also a limitation of the MMP analyses presented here.
    In addition to the rat clearance example discussed above, we provide a second example illustrating how a subset of assays behaves in comparison to the composite across all assays interrogated for a given parameter. Figure S3 in the Supporting Information illustrates for CH group → N atom exchanges how the MMP statistics for a subset of 1163 MMPs associated with a subgroup of 792 antiproliferative assays differs from that of the entire set of functional activities for 19 335 MMPs derived from 7568 assays. In this example, the observed differences are small. A ≥3-fold decrease in functional activity is observed for 24% (22%) of the antiproliferative (all functional) assays, while the fraction of MMPs with ≥3-fold increased functional activity is unchanged. Additional detailed analyses could be performed for other pharmacological parameters and assay subsets; however, the vast number of assays in ChEMBL24 renders such analyses prohibitive and beyond the scope of this work. The examples discussed here are arbitrary; however, it remains to point out that each assay has its own potential for achieving the desired parameter changes by leveraging positional analogue scanning. In summary, Figure 6 illustrates that the four structure modifications highlighted in this Perspective have important positional analogue dependencies for impacts on an array of pharmacological parameters frequently encountered during multiparameter optimization.

    Nitrogen Scanning Case Studies

    An example of nitrogen scanning to improve potency is shown in Figure 7.(35) As part of a program to identify splicing modulators of survival motor neuron-2 premessenger ribonucleic acid (SMN2 pre-mRNA), compound 26 was screened along with diaza-analogues 27–29, of which only positional analogue 29 was found to increase SMN protein levels (SMN EC50 = 0.60 nM, 2.5-fold increase, FI). Further optimization of 29 was undertaken to increase potency and reduce hERG binding (hERG IC50 = 0.60 μM), as well as to improve pharmacokinetic (PK) and neuroPK profiles. Exchange of the aniline NH group of 29 with an O atom and the 2-benzo[b]thiophenyl ring system of 29 with a 2-(5-(1H-pyrazol-4-yl))phenolyl ring system afforded clinical candidate 30 (SMN EC50 = 0.020 nM, 3.6-fold increase; hERG IC50 = 6.3 μM). Interestingly, ortho-hydroxyl groups in several precursors of 30 were found to be critical for inducing planar conformations and high potencies, suggesting that a N → S interaction between the proximal N atom of the pyridazine ring of 29 and the adjacent S atom of the benzothiophene ring system of 29 may give rise to a planar conformation and the favorable activity cliff observed for 29 compared to 26–28 (Figure 7).(36) The finding that only one of the three positional analogues tested gave improved potency is in line with the MMP analysis-derived probability of 15% for achieving ≥3-fold increases in potency (Figure 5).
    An example of nitrogen scanning to increase microsomal stability is summarized in Figure 8.(37) In a program seeking potent, selective, and orally bioavailable inhibitors of cyclin-dependent kinase 8 (CDK8), lead compound 31 was identified. Though 31 displays excellent biochemical and cellular potency toward CDK8 (CDK8 and 7dF3 cell IC50 = 1.4 and 0.60 nM, respectively), it also exhibits poor stability in human, rat, and mouse liver microsomes (HLM, RLM, and MLM CLint = 530, 79, and 240 μL min–1 mg–1, respectively). Nitrogen scanning of the indazole ring system of 31 was undertaken to reduce lipophilicity and probe impacts on potency and microsomal stability. Of the three monoaza-analogues of 31 prepared and tested (32–34), only positional analogue 34 retains favorable potency toward CDK8 (CDK8 and 7dF3 cell IC50 = 2.6 and 6.5 nM, respectively) and displays markedly improved stability in human, rat, and mouse liver microsomes (HLM, RLM, and MLM CLint = 45, <10, and <10 μL min–1 mg–1, respectively). Compound 34 was selected as the preclinical candidate and advanced into in vivo efficacy and safety studies. As with the case studies discussed above, it is interesting to note the observation of several activity cliffs in converting 31 to monoaza-analogues 32–34 (Figure 8). Both the detrimental impact of some positional analogues on potency and the improved microsomal stability for most positional analogues are expected given the MMP analysis probability distributions for these pharmacological parameters in Figure 5, which suggests a higher propensity of increasing microsomal stability ≥3-fold and decreasing clearance ≥3-fold for CH group → N atom exchanges.
    An example of iterative nitrogen scanning to increase microsomal stability, reduce CYP 3A4 inhibition, and ablate PXR activity is illustrated in Figure 9.(38) As part of a program seeking palm site allosteric inhibitors of hepatitis C virus NS5B replicase (HCV NS5B replicase), lead compound 35 was identified. Though 35 displays excellent potency toward several HCV replicons (gt-1b, gt-1a, and gt-1bC316N EC50 = 1.3, 2.1, and 35 nM, respectively), it also exhibits poor stability in human liver microsomes (HLM t1/2 = 11 min), as well as inhibition of CYP 3A4 (CYP 3A4 IC50 = 2.1 μM). Because a metabolite identification study on a precursor of 35 had identified the left-most phenyl ring as a metabolic soft-spot, nitrogen scanning of this ring of 35 was undertaken to increase polarity and potentially block metabolic sites. Of the three monoaza-analogues of 35 prepared and tested (36–38), only positional analogue 36 both retains favorable potency across HCV replicons (gt-1b, gt-1a, and gt-1bC316N EC50 = 1.9, 2.8, and 55 nM, respectively) and displays markedly improved stability in human liver microsomes (HLM t1/2 = 110 min). Unfortunately, 36 also exhibits inhibition of CYP 3A4 and hERG (CYP 3A4 IC50 = 4.1 μM; hERG IC50 = 5.8 μM) and activation of PXR (PXR EC50 = 1.6 μM). A second iteration of nitrogen scanning of the left-most ring of 36 was initiated to further decrease lipophilicity and potentially reduce these off-target liabilities. Of the four diaza-analogues of 36 prepared and tested (39–42), only positional analogue 42 retains favorable potency across HCV replicons (gt-1b, gt-1a, and gt-1bC316N EC50 = 1.0, 2.3, and 51 nM, respectively), displays excellent stability in human liver microsomes (HLM t1/2 > 120 min), exhibits reduced inhibition of CYP 3A4 (CYP 3A4 IC50 = 11 μM), and shows no activation of PXR (PXR EC50 > 50 μM). Unfortunately, 42 displays inhibition of hERG (hERG IC50 = 4.8 μM). Exchange of the C4 CH group of the benzofuran ring system of 42 with a CF group afforded 43, which retains favorable potency across HCV replicons (gt-1b, gt-1a, and gt-1bC316N EC50 = 4.0, 9.0, and 18 nM, respectively), exhibits excellent stability in human liver microsomes (HLM t1/2 > 120 min), displays reduced inhibition of CYP 3A4 and hERG (CYP 3A4 IC50 > 13 μM; hERG IC50 = 24 μM), and shows no activation of PXR (PXR EC50 > 50 μM). Compound 43 was advanced into clinical trials. As with the case studies discussed above, the observation of several activity cliffs in converting 35 to mono- and diaza-analogues 36–42 is notable (Figure 9). Additionally, maintaining a low level of CYP 3A4 inhibition for 2-aza-analogue 36 while observing strong increases in CYP 3A4 inhibition for 4-aza-analogue 38 is in line with the positional analogue analysis in Figure 6, which suggests a 40% chance of decreasing CYP inhibition ≥3-fold for 2-aza-analogues and a 40% chance of increasing CYP inhibition ≥3-fold for 4-aza-analogues.

    Fluorine Scanning Case Studies

    An example of fluorine scanning to improve potency is shown in Figure 10.(39) In a program searching for selective ATP-competitive inhibitors of protein kinase B (PKB/Akt), racemic lead compound 44 was found to exhibit modest potency toward Akt, but with favorable lipophilicity (Akt IC50 = 62 nM; cLogP = 1.7). Fluorine scanning of the readily modifiable phenyl ring of 44 was undertaken to probe impacts on potency with minimal effect on lipophilicity. Of the three monofluoro-analogues of 44 prepared and tested (45–47), positional analogue 47 exhibits the best balance of potency and lipophilicity (Akt IC50 = 7.4 nM; cLogP = 2.0). Resolution of the enantiomers of 47, exchange of the Me group with an Et group, and substitution of the ortho CH group of the phenyl ring with a CF group afforded clinical candidate 48 (Akt IC50 = 0.50 nM; cLogP = 2.4). The positional analogue analyses in Figure 6 suggest that there are negligible differences in binding affinity or functional activity impacts between 2-, 3-, and 4-fluoro-analogues. Overall, the chances of observing ≥3-fold increases in potency versus ≥3-fold decreases in potency are higher for all positional analogues, although the chances are somewhat smaller for 4-fluoro-analogues. In that regard, the significant improvement in potency for 4-fluoro-analogue 47 is somewhat surprising.
    An example of fluorine scanning to increase microsomal stability and improve PK and neuroPK profiles is summarized in Figure 11.(40) As part of a program seeking potent and selective inhibitors of phosphodiesterase 1 (PDE1), lead compound 49 was discovered. Though 49 displays excellent potency toward PDE1 and selectivity against PDE4A (PDE1 and PDE4A Ki = 0.085 and 240 nM, respectively), it also exhibits poor stability in human liver microsomes (HLM CLint = 190 mL min–1 kg–1). Fluorine scanning of the pyridyl ring of 49 was undertaken to probe impacts on potency and microsomal stability. Of the four monofluoro-analogues of 49 prepared and tested (50–53), positional analogue 53 displays the best balance of potency and stability in human liver microsomes (PDE1 Ki = 0.058 nM; HLM CLint = 80 mL min–1 kg–1). From comparison of the PK and neuroPK profiles of 49 and 53 after single 10 mg/kg oral doses in mice, 53 possesses superior profiles (49, Cmax,plasma = 48 ng/mL, Cmax,brain = 28 ng/mL, brain/plasma ratio = 0.32; 53, Cmax,plasma = 490 ng/mL, Cmax,brain = 390 ng/mL, brain/plasma ratio = 0.71). Compound 53 was advanced into clinical trials. The increased brain/plasma ratio of compound 53 is not surprising given the 21% chance of achieving ≥3-fold increases in brain uptake for CH group → CF group exchanges versus the 7% chance of observing ≥3-fold decreases, as suggested by the MMP analysis in Figure 5.
    An example of fluorine scanning to increase oral bioavailability and avoid hERG and CYP 1A2 inhibition is illustrated in Figure 12.(41) In a program searching for selective antagonists of the class A GPCR orexin-2 receptor (OX2R), lead compound 54 was identified. Though 54 displays good potency toward OX2R and selectivity against OX1R (OX2R Ki = 12 nM; OX1R Ki = 1600 nM), it also exhibits poor stability in rat liver microsomes and low oral bioavailability in rat (RLM ER = 0.79; F = 8.0%). Fluorine scanning of the phenyl ring of 54 was undertaken to probe impacts on potency and PK properties, including oral bioavailability. Of the four monofluoro-analogues of 54 prepared and tested (55–58), positional analogue 55 displays the best balance of potency toward OX2R and selectivity against OX1R (OX2R Ki = 10 nM; OX1R Ki = 800 nM), oral bioavailability in rat (F = 24%), and no inhibition of hERG or CYP 1A2 (hERG IC50 > 10 μM; CYP 1A2 IC50 > 10 μM). Compound 55 was advanced into clinical trials.

    Methyl Scanning Case Studies

    An example of methyl scanning to improve potency and cellular permeability is shown in Figure 13.(42) As part of a program targeting potent inhibitors of human immunodeficiency virus type 1 (HIV-1), lead compound 59 was identified. Although 59 possesses good potency toward HIV-1 and excellent stability in human liver microsomes (HIV-1 EC50 = 0.58 nM; HLM t1/2 > 100 min), it also exhibits poor cellular permeability (Caco-2 Pc < 15 nm/s). Methyl scanning of the pyrazole ring of 59 was undertaken to probe the impacts on potency and permeability. Of the three monomethyl-analogues of 59 prepared and tested (60–62), positional analogue 60 displays the most improved potency toward HIV-1 with a significant increase in cellular permeability (HIV-1 EC50 = 0.050 nM; Caco-2 Pc = 260 nm/s), albeit with somewhat diminished stability in human liver microsomes (HLM %R at 10 min = 80). Compound 63 arose from CH group → N atom exchange and was shown to have good potency toward HIV-1, excellent stability in human liver microsomes, and favorable cellular permeability (HIV-1 EC50 = 0.10 nM; HLM %R at 10 min = 98; Caco-2 Pc = 180 nm/s). Compound 63 was advanced into clinical trials; however, the azaindole NH group of 63 was subsequently linked to a phosphonooxymethyl prodrug moiety to improve pharmaceutical properties and oral bioavailability. The increased permeabilities observed for the CH group → CMe group exchanges are concordant with the greater likelihood of ≥3-fold increases suggested by the MMP analysis in Figure 5.
    Another example of methyl scanning to improve potency and membrane permeability is summarized in Figure 14.(43) In a program seeking potent agonists of peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor γ (PPARγ), lead compound 64 was identified. Compound 64 exhibits poor potency toward PPARγ in a cell assay, which was proposed to be due to low lipophilicity and modest membrane permeability (PPARγ EC50, Emax = 1100 nM, 74%; log D7.4 = 0.40; PAMPA Papp = 2.2 × 10–6 cm/s). Methyl scanning of the pyridine ring of 64 was undertaken to interrogate impacts on potency, lipophilicity, and membrane permeability. Of the four monomethyl-analogues of 64 prepared and tested (65–68), positional analogues 66 and 68 display the best balance of potency, lipophilicity, and permeability (66, PPARγ EC50, Emax = 130 nM, 42%; log D7.4 = 0.90; PAMPA Papp = 4.8 × 10–6 cm/s; 68, PPARγ EC50, Emax = 350 nM, 83%; log D7.4 = 0.90; PAMPA Papp = 6.0 × 10–6 cm/s). Combining favored positional analogues 66 and 68 afforded clinical candidate 69 (PPARγ EC50, Emax = 41 nM, 68%; log D7.4 = 1.4; PAMPA Papp = 13 × 10–6 cm/s). The favorable additive SAR for potency, lipophilicity, and membrane permeability is notable and in line with observed probabilities from the MMP analyses (Figure 5). The higher impacts of 2-methyl-analogues 68 and 69 on permeability are also in agreement with the significantly higher chance of 2-methyl-analogues compared to 3- or 4-methyl-analogues improving permeability ≥3-fold, as observed in the positional analogue analyses (Figure 6).
    An example of methyl scanning to reduce hERG inhibition is illustrated in Figure 15.(44) As part of a program targeting potent inhibitors of integrin receptor αvβ6 (αvβ6), lead compound 70 was identified. Although 70 displays desirable potency toward αvβ6 (αvβ6 pIC50 = 8.6), it also exhibits undesirable inhibition of hERG (hERG pIC50 = 6.1). Methyl scanning of the pyrazole ring of 70 was investigated to probe impacts on potency and hERG activity. Of the three monomethyl-analogues of 70 prepared and tested (71–73), positional analogues 71 and 73 provided the desired potency toward αvβ6 as well as reduced inhibition of hERG (71, αvβ6 pIC50 = 8.4, hERG pIC50 = 5.0; 73, αvβ6 pIC50 = 8.8, hERG pIC50 = 4.6). Combining favored positional analogues 71 and 73 gave clinical candidate 74 (αvβ6 pIC50 = 8.4; hERG pIC50 = 4.9). The observation of reduced hERG inhibition upon increased methyl substitution and greater lipophilicity is unexpected, both intuitively and based on the MMP analysis in Figure 5.

    Hydroxyl Scanning Case Studies

    An example of hydroxyl scanning to improve potency and membrane permeability is shown in Figure 16.(45) In a program pursuing inhibitors of phosphodiesterase 4D (PDE4D) and self-induced aggregation of β-amyloid 1–42 (Aβ1–42), early lead compound 75 was identified. Compound 75 displays poor potency toward PDE4D and self-induced aggregation of Aβ1–42 (PDE4D2 IC50 = 3.1 μM; Aβ1–42 SIA = 19%), as well as limited membrane permeability (PAMPA Pe = 2.6 × 10–6 cm/s). Hydroxyl scanning of the benzofuran ring system of 75 was initiated to interrogate impacts on potency and permeability. Of the three monohydroxy-analogues of 75 prepared and tested (76–78), positional analogue 78 exhibits improved potency toward PDE4D and self-induced aggregation of Aβ1–42 (PDE4D2 IC50 = 0.96 nM; Aβ1–42 SIA = 59%), as well as improved membrane permeability (PAMPA Pe = 21 × 10–6 cm/s). Compound 79 arose from Cl atom → I atom exchange on the quinoline ring system of 78 and was selected as an advanced lead compound (PDE4D2 IC50 = 0.32 μM; Aβ1–42 SIA = 68%; PAMPA Pe = 19 × 10–6 cm/s). The finding of improved membrane permeability upon increased hydroxyl substitution is unexpected, although the preference for ≥3-fold decreases versus ≥3-fold increases in permeability observed in the MMP analysis in Figure 5 is not statistically significant.
    An example of hydroxyl scanning to reduce inhibition of hERG and CYP 2D6 is summarized in Figure 17.(46,47) As part of a program seeking potent agonists of the δ-opioid receptor (DOR), lead compound 80 was identified. Though 80 possesses good potency toward DOR (DOR EC50 = 19 nM), it also displays undesirable inhibition of hERG and CYP 2D6 (hERG IC50 = 7.9 μM; CYP 2D6 IC50 = 4.3 μM). Hydroxyl scanning of 80 was undertaken to probe impacts on potency toward DOR and inhibition of hERG and CYP 2D6. Of the six monohydroxy-analogues of 80 prepared and tested (81–86), positional analogues 81 and 85 exhibit a favorable balance of potency toward DOR and decreased inhibition of hERG and CYP 2D6 (81, DOR EC50 = 20 nM, hERG IC50 = 78 μM, CYP 2D6 IC50 = NR; 85, DOR EC50 = 94 nM, hERG IC50 = 57 μM, CYP 2D6 IC50 = 43 μM). Compounds 81 and 85 were advanced into clinical trials. The 10-fold decrease in CYP 2D6 inhibition observed in going from 80 to 85 is in line with the MMP analysis in Figure 5, which suggests a 27% chance of decreasing CYP inhibition ≥3-fold versus a 10% chance of increasing CYP inhibition ≥3-fold for CH group → COH group exchanges.

    Conclusion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    In this Perspective, positional analogue scanning has been shown to be an effective strategy for multiparameter optimization in drug design, whereby substantial improvements in a variety of pharmacological parameters can be achieved with minimal structure modifications. When rational drug design is not sufficiently supported by structural information on the target and key antitargets and predictive models for key optimization parameters are unavailable, positional analogue scanning allows for the systematic exploration of alternative scaffolds and the preparation of focused libraries in the pursuit of multiparameter optimization. Positional analogue scanning can be considered when a high-value hit has been identified and systematic hit expansion is desired. Furthermore, if an advanced lead has been obtained and other, less synthesis-intensive multiparameter optimization approaches have been exhausted, positional analogue scanning can provide an attractive optimization strategy. As Poongavanam, Liu, Zhan, and coauthors stated in a recent Perspective on strategic advances in medicinal chemistry, “no single strategy is likely to be a universal panacea”; for context, a list of medicinal chemistry strategies including their general merits and drawbacks is included in the Supporting Information (Table S9).(48)
    For high-value hits or early lead compounds, when the primary goals are to identify issues and assess feasibility for multiparameter optimization, full positional analogue scanning using diverse structure modifications is recommended (Figure 18). One may consider beginning with privileged structure modifications (exchange of CH groups with N atoms or CF, CMe, or COH groups) and then extending to other common structure modifications as the SAR suggests (e.g., exchange of CH groups with CCN, CCl, CCF3, or COMe groups). For advanced lead compounds, when the primary goals are to address issues and optimize profiles, targeted positional analogue scanning on selected rings using specific structure modifications is recommended (Figure 18). What form of positional analogue scanning to use and what extent of pharmacological profiling to perform depend on the optimization challenges encountered or anticipated. For example, to improve potency, solubility, and CYP inhibition, one may consider nitrogen or hydroxyl scanning; to improve potency and permeability, one may consider fluorine or methyl scanning. Sequential positional analogue scanning may be considered to seek the potentially additive benefits of each structure modification (e.g., nitrogen scanning followed by fluorine scanning, etc.). If no meaningful improvements in pharmacological profiles have been realized by positional analogue scanning using the four privileged structure modifications, then other optimization approaches may be considered.
    Matched molecular pair and positional analogue analyses performed on ChEMBL data provide probabilities for observing significant impacts on a variety of pharmacological parameters upon positional analogue scanning (Figures 5 and 6). The probability to observe these impacts varies across pharmacological parameters, structure modifications, and positional analogues. In many cases, meaningful improvements in targeted pharmacological parameters can be achieved, often in line with probabilistic expectations. However, some of the case studies also demonstrate that impacts can be serendipitous. Importantly, the impacts evoked by a single positional analogue across multiple pharmacological parameters could not be reasonably predicted here because covariate pharmacological parameter dependencies were not elucidated in the MMP analyses. It is also important to note that the impacts on multiple parameters that arise from specific positional analogues are often insular and uncorrelated, making it difficult to assess whether maximal progress has been made toward the desired goal and when to stop; hence, full positional analogue scanning is recommended whenever feasible.
    Although the impacts of positional analogue scanning generally cannot be predicted with high confidence for each individual case, the modern need in chemical biology and drug discovery for rapid and simultaneous multiparameter optimization justifies the synthesis investment that may be required for positional analogue scanning. To this end, it is important to render positional analogue scanning more efficient by the development of more synthetic methods that enable all positional analogues to be generated simultaneously or in parallel by late-stage functionalization or by an increased variety of commercially available building blocks that allow expedient synthetic routes for de novo syntheses of all positional analogues. Finally, it is hoped that the MMP analyses and case studies of how positional analogue scanning has been leveraged to overcome multiparameter optimization challenges for the identification of advanced leads, preclinical candidates, and clinical candidates will serve to inspire and guide the effective use of this strategy in drug design.

    Abbreviations Used
    pKa

    negative logarithm of the acid dissociation constant

    log P

    logarithm of the octanol/water partition coefficient

    cLogP

    calculated log P

    log DpH

    logarithm of the octanol/water distribution coefficient at a specified pH

    SH2O

    solubility in water

    SSBF

    solubility in a simulated biological fluid

    ER

    efflux ratio or extraction ratio

    CLint

    intrinsic clearance

    NR

    not reported or not reportable

    Emax

    percent maximal activation versus basal or a reference standard

    RLM

    rat liver microsome

    LLC-PK1

    porcine proximal tubule cells

    Cu,plasma

    unbound compound concentration in plasma

    PLC

    peripheral lymphocyte count

    POC

    percent-of-control

    SFaSSIF

    solubility in fasted-state simulated intestinal fluid

    HLM

    human liver microsome

    MMP

    matched molecular pair

    FI

    fold increase

    PK

    pharmacokinetic

    MLM

    mouse liver microsome

    Cmax plasma

    maximal compound concentration in plasma

    Caco-2

    Caucasian colon adenocarcinoma cells

    Papp, Pc, or Pe

    membrane permeability

    %R

    percent remaining

    SIA

    self-induced aggregation

    1. 1
      (a) Garbaccio, R. M.; Parmee, E. R. The impact of chemical probes in drug discovery: a pharmaceutical industry perspective. Cell Chem. Biol. 2016, 23, 10– 16,  DOI: 10.1016/j.chembiol.2015.11.011
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      1a
      The Impact of Chemical Probes in Drug Discovery: A Pharmaceutical Industry Perspective
      Garbaccio, Robert M.; Parmee, Emma R.
      Cell Chemical Biology (2016), 23 (1), 10-17CODEN: CCBEBM; ISSN:2451-9448. (Cell Press)
      Chem. probes represent an important component of both academic and pharmaceutical drug discovery research. As a complement to prior reviews that have defined this scientific field, we aim to provide an industry perspective on the value of having high-quality chem. probes throughout the course of preclin. research. By studying examples from the internal Merck pipeline, we recognize that these probes require significant collaborative investment to realize their potential impact in clarifying the tractability and translation of a given therapeutic target. This perspective concludes with recommendations for chem. probe discovery aimed toward maximizing their potential to identify targets that result in the successful delivery of novel therapeutics.

      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      1b
      The promise and peril of chemical probes
      Arrowsmith, Cheryl H.; Audia, James E.; Austin, Christopher; Baell, Jonathan; Bennett, Jonathan; Blagg, Julian; Bountra, Chas; Brennan, Paul E.; Brown, Peter J.; Bunnage, Mark E.; Buser-Doepner, Carolyn; Campbell, Robert M.; Carter, Adrian J.; Cohen, Philip; Copeland, Robert A.; Cravatt, Ben; Dahlin, Jayme L.; Dhanak, Dashyant; Edwards, Aled M.; Frye, Stephen V.; Gray, Nathanael; Grimshaw, Charles E.; Hepworth, David; Howe, Trevor; Huber, Kilian V. M.; Jin, Jian; Knapp, Stefan; Kotz, Joanne D.; Kruger, Ryan G.; Lowe, Derek; Mader, Mary M.; Marsden, Brian; Mueller-Fahrnow, Anke; Muller, Susanne; O'Hagan, Ronan C.; Overington, John P.; Owen, Dafydd R.; Rosenberg, Saul H.; Roth, Brian; Ross, Ruth; Schapira, Matthieu; Schreiber, Stuart L.; Shoichet, Brian; Sundstrom, Michael; Superti-Furga, Giulio; Taunton, Jack; Toledo-Sherman, Leticia; Walpole, Chris; Walters, Michael A.; Willson, Timothy M.; Workman, Paul; Young, Robert N.; Zuercher, William J.
      Nature Chemical Biology (2015), 11 (8), 536-541CODEN: NCBABT; ISSN:1552-4450. (Nature Publishing Group)
      Chem. probes are powerful reagents with increasing impacts on biomedical research. However, probes of poor quality or that are used incorrectly generate misleading results. To help address these shortcomings, we will create a community-driven wiki resource to improve quality and convey current best practice.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXht1Wlu7zO&md5=d8c7a7af94921ab4cdcc871487cceadd
    2. 2
      (a) Meanwell, N. A. Improving drug design: an update on recent applications of efficiency metrics, strategies for replacing problematic elements, and compounds in nontraditional drug space. Chem. Res. Toxicol. 2016, 29, 564– 616,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrestox.6b00043
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      2a
      Improving Drug Design: An Update on Recent Applications of Efficiency Metrics, Strategies for Replacing Problematic Elements, and Compounds in Nontraditional Drug Space
      Meanwell, Nicholas A.
      Chemical Research in Toxicology (2016), 29 (4), 564-616CODEN: CRTOEC; ISSN:0893-228X. (American Chemical Society)
      Drug discovery and development is a complex and lengthy enterprise that suffers from high rates of candidate attrition at all stages of the process. The phys., biol., and toxicol. properties of a drug candidate are inextricably linked to its structure, and once a mol. has been synthesized, all subsequent studies along the development path are focused only on assessing and understanding its properties in greater detail. Unfortunately, a full prediction of the biol. properties of a mol. from an anal. of its 2- or 3-dimensional structure is currently beyond our expertise. This backdrop mandates that considerable care be taken at the design stage if a mol. is to be successful in testing a mechanistic concept underlying a disease process and to progress into late stage clin. trials and, ultimately, marketing approval. While there are multiple potential causes of candidate attrition, an introspective anal. of drug design practices over the past decade has focused attention on the perception that contemporary mols. are unnecessarily obese, burdened by high mol. wt. and excessive lipophilicity. This practice is believed to have its roots in the singular pursuit of enhancing potency during lead optimization rather than adopting a more holistic approach to drug design that gives broader consideration to how structural features affect developability properties. In an effort to provide the medicinal chem. community with practical guideposts to enhancing compd. quality in the drug design phase and which can readily be applied, a series of efficiency indexes have been proposed that attempt to define aspects of compd. quality in the context of a series of physicochem. parameters. Of these metrics, lipophilic ligand efficiency (LLE or LipE), which provides an index of the dependence of the potency of a mol. on its intrinsic lipophilicity, has been characterized as the most robust metric that has potential for broad-based application. In this review, after describing the background literature behind the derivation of efficiency metrics and approaches to assessing compd. aesthetics, synopses of some recent practical application in lead optimization campaigns are presented. However, mols. that fall into space beyond that assocd. with traditional drug-like properties are an important part of the current and future landscape, exemplified by the summary of direct acting hepatitis C virus NS3 and NS5A inhibitors that have transformed clin. therapy for this chronic disease. While drug development in nontraditional drug-like space is more challenging and the rules for compd. quality will be different with much still to be understood, careful and disciplined drug design practices will be an essential element of success.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XktVCrs7Y%253D&md5=aef48399fb698b5f958c1cc11e1d25aa
      .
      (b) Abou-Gharbia, M.; Childers, W. E. Discovery of innovative therapeutics: today’s realities and tomorrow’s vision. 2. Pharma’s challenges and their commitment to innovation. J. Med. Chem. 2014, 57, 5525– 5553,  DOI: 10.1021/jm401564r
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      2b
      Discovery of Innovative Therapeutics: Today's Realities and Tomorrow's Vision. 2. Pharma's Challenges and Their Commitment to Innovation
      Abou-Gharbia, Magid; Childers, Wayne E.
      Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2014), 57 (13), 5525-5553CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. The pharmaceutical industry is facing enormous challenges, including reduced efficiency, stagnant success rate, patent expirations for key drugs, fierce price competition from generics, high regulatory hurdles, and the industry's perceived tarnished image. Pharma has responded by embarking on a range of initiatives. Other sectors, including NIH, have also responded. Academic drug discovery groups have appeared to support the transition of innovative academic discoveries and ideas into attractive drug discovery opportunities. Part 1 of this two-part series discussed the criticisms that have been leveled at the pharmaceutical industry over the past 3 decades and summarized the supporting data for and against these criticisms. This second installment will focus on the current challenges facing the pharmaceutical industry and Pharma's responses, focusing on the industry's changing perspective and new business models for coping with the loss of talent and declining clin. pipelines as well as presenting some examples of recent drug discovery successes.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXotVeksw%253D%253D&md5=81598458e7db3879f2e5bb67d5b40eb3
      .
      (c) Paul, S. M.; Mytelka, D. S.; Dunwiddie, C. T.; Persinger, C. C.; Munos, B. H.; Lindborg, S. R.; Schacht, A. L. How to improve R&D productivity: the pharmaceutical industry’s grand challenge. Nat. Rev. Drug Discovery 2010, 9, 203– 214,  DOI: 10.1038/nrd3078
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      2c
      How to improve R&D productivity: the pharmaceutical industry's grand challenge
      Paul, Steven M.; Mytelka, Daniel S.; Dunwiddie, Christopher T.; Persinger, Charles C.; Munos, Bernard H.; Lindborg, Stacy R.; Schacht, Aaron L.
      Nature Reviews Drug Discovery (2010), 9 (3), 203-214CODEN: NRDDAG; ISSN:1474-1776. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A review. The pharmaceutical industry is under growing pressure from a range of environmental issues, including major losses of revenue owing to patent expirations, increasingly cost-constrained healthcare systems and more demanding regulatory requirements. In our view, the key to tackling the challenges such issues pose to both the future viability of the pharmaceutical industry and advances in healthcare is to substantially increase the no. and quality of innovative, cost-effective new medicines, without incurring unsustainable R&D costs. However, it is widely acknowledged that trends in industry R&D productivity have been moving in the opposite direction for a no. of years. Here, we present a detailed anal. based on comprehensive, recent, industry-wide data to identify the relative contributions of each of the steps in the drug discovery and development process to overall R&D productivity. We then propose specific strategies that could have the most substantial impact in improving R&D productivity.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXitFemsbg%253D&md5=2f32bcc48c869290eef18ff9400afcc5
    3. 3
      Hajduk, P. J.; Sauer, D. R. Statistical analysis of the effects of common chemical substituents on ligand potency. J. Med. Chem. 2008, 51, 553– 564,  DOI: 10.1021/jm070838y
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      3
      Statistical Analysis of the Effects of Common Chemical Substituents on Ligand Potency
      Hajduk, Philip J.; Sauer, Daryl R.
      Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2008), 51 (3), 553-564CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
      The results of a statistical anal. of more than 84000 compds. from lead optimization programs against 30 different protein targets is presented, with a focus on the effects that different chem. substituents have on compd. potency. It is obsd. that the potency changes induced by most chem. groups follows a nearly normal distribution centered near zero (i.e., no effect on potency). However, the widths of the distributions vary significantly between different substituents, and these effects cannot be rationalized by simple physicochem. parameters. In addn., certain substituents consistently bias the distribution toward higher or lower potency, suggesting the existence of preferred and nonpreferred chem. groups for lead optimization. The implications of these results for understanding protein-ligand recognition and for enhancing the efficiency and speed of lead optimization will be discussed.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXjt1ejtQ%253D%253D&md5=396d02789aece9be31fe3508fbabca7d
    4. 4
      (a) Pennington, L. D. Leveraging the Necessary Nitrogen Atom in Chemical Biology and Drug Discovery. Presented at the 258th National Meeting of the American Chemical Society, San Diego Convention Center, San Diego, CA, August 27, 2019.
      Google Scholar
      There is no corresponding record for this reference.
      (b) Pennington, L. D.; Moustakas, D. T. The necessary nitrogen atom: a versatile high-impact design element for multiparameter optimization. J. Med. Chem. 2017, 60, 3552– 3579,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.jmedchem.6b01807
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      4b
      The Necessary Nitrogen Atom: A Versatile High-Impact Design Element for Multiparameter Optimization
      Pennington, Lewis D.; Moustakas, Demetri T.
      Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2017), 60 (9), 3552-3579CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. There is a continued desire in biomedical research to reduce the no. and duration of design cycles required to optimize lead compds. into high-quality chem. probes or safe and efficacious drug candidates. The insightful application of impactful mol. design elements is one approach toward achieving this goal. The replacement of a CH group with a N atom in arom. and heteroarom. ring systems can have many important effects on mol. and physicochem. properties and intra- and intermol. interactions that can translate to improved pharmacol. profiles. In this Perspective, the "necessary nitrogen atom" is shown to be a versatile high-impact design element for multiparameter optimization, wherein ≥10-, 100-, or 1000-fold improvement in a variety of key pharmacol. parameters can be realized.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXit1yit74%253D&md5=002aaee48995e7954647a1f75183db4d

      (c) Boger, D. L. The difference a single atom can make: synthesis and design at the chemistry–biology interface. J. Org. Chem. 2017, 82, 11961– 11980,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.joc.7b02088
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      4c
      The Difference a Single Atom Can Make: Synthesis and Design at the Chemistry-Biology Interface
      Boger, Dale L.
      Journal of Organic Chemistry (2017), 82 (23), 11961-11980CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263. (American Chemical Society)
      A Perspective of work in our lab. on the examn. of biol. active compds., esp. natural products, is presented. In the context of individual programs and along with a summary of our work, selected cases are presented that illustrate the impact single atom changes can have on the biol. properties of the compds. The examples were chosen to highlight single heavy atom changes that improve activity, rather than those that involve informative alterations that reduce or abolish activity. The examples were also chosen to illustrate that the impact of such single-atom changes can originate from steric, electronic, conformational, or H-bonding effects, from changes in functional reactivity, from fundamental intermol. interactions with a biol. target, from introduction of a new or altered functionalization site, or from features as simple as improvements in stability or phys. properties. Nearly all the examples highlighted represent not only unusual instances of productive deep-seated natural product modifications and were introduced through total synthesis but are also remarkable in that they are derived from only a single heavy atom change in the structure.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXhsFGhs7%252FE&md5=1ed0b2ee9315842d41e6efec8f97ed2c
    5. 5
      (a) Schönherr, H.; Cernak, T. Profound methyl effects in drug discovery and a call for new C–H methylation reactions. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2013, 52, 12256– 12267,  DOI: 10.1002/anie.201303207
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      5a
      Profound methyl effects in drug discovery and a call for new C-H methylation reactions
      Schonherr Heike; Cernak Tim
      Angewandte Chemie (International ed. in English) (2013), 52 (47), 12256-67 ISSN:.
      The methyl group is one of the most commonly occurring carbon fragments in small-molecule drugs. This simplest alkyl fragment appears in more than 67 % of the top-selling drugs of 2011 and can modulate both the biological and physical properties of a molecule. This Review focuses on so-called magic methyl effects on binding potency, where the seemingly mundane change of C H to C Me improves the IC50 value of a drug candidate more than 100-fold. This discussion is followed by a survey of recent advances in synthetic chemistry that allow the direct methylation of C(sp(2) ) H and C(sp(3) ) H bonds. It is our hope that the relevance of the meager methyl group to drug discovery as presented herein will inspire reports on new C H methylation reactions.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC2c%252FptVahuw%253D%253D&md5=ef08f80e55b2c530b49e4306da024902
      .
      (b) Leung, C. S.; Leung, S. S. F.; Tirado-Rives, J.; Jorgensen, W. L. Methyl effects on protein–ligand binding. J. Med. Chem. 2012, 55, 4489– 4500,  DOI: 10.1021/jm3003697
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      5b
      Methyl Effects on Protein-Ligand Binding
      Leung, Cheryl S.; Leung, Siegfried S. F.; Tirado-Rives, Julian; Jorgensen, William L.
      Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2012), 55 (9), 4489-4500CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
      The effects of addn. of a Me group to a lead compd. on biol. activity are examd. A literature anal. of >2000 cases reveals that an activity boost of a factor of 10 or more is found with an 8% frequency, and a 100-fold boost is a 1 in 200 event. Four cases in the latter category are analyzed in depth to elucidate any unusual aspects of the protein-ligand binding, distribution of water mols., and changes in conformational energetics. The analyses include Monte Carlo/free-energy perturbation (MC/FEP) calcns. for Me replacements in inhibitor series for p38α MAP kinase, ACK1, PTP1B, and thrombin. Me substitutions ortho to an aryl ring can be particularly effective at improving activity by inducing a propitious conformational change. The greatest improvements in activity arise from coupling the conformational gain with the burial of the Me group in a hydrophobic region of the protein.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XlsV2iu7Y%253D&md5=0ea58d9c1bf845d383931b6a017f9b37
      .
      (c) Meanwell, N. A. Fluorine and fluorinated motifs in the design and application of bioisosteres for drug design. J. Med. Chem. 2018, 61, 5822– 5880,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.jmedchem.7b01788
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      5c
      Fluorine and Fluorinated Motifs in the Design and Application of Bioisosteres for Drug Design
      Meanwell, Nicholas A.
      Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2018), 61 (14), 5822-5880CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
      The electronic properties and relatively small size of fluorine endow it with considerable versatility as a bioisostere and it has found application as a substitute for lone pairs of electrons, the hydrogen atom, and the Me group while also acting as a functional mimetic of the carbonyl, carbinol, andnitrile moieties. In this context, fluorine substitution can influence the potency, conformation, metab., membrane permeability, and P-gp recognition of a mol. and temper inhibition of the hERG channel by basic amines. However, as a consequence of the unique properties of fluorine, it features prominently in the design of higher order structural metaphors that are more esoteric in their conception and which reflect a more sophisticated mol. construction that broadens biol. mimesis. In this Perspective, applications of fluorine in the construction of bioisosteric elements designed to enhance the in vitro and in vivo properties of a mol. are summarized.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXitV2qu7w%253D&md5=2d0ce3326c7ff932da8d7d26972ced14
      .
      (d) Wang, Y.; Du, Y.; Huang, N. A survey of the role of nitrile groups in protein–ligand interactions. Future Med. Chem. 2018, 10, 2713– 2728,  DOI: 10.4155/fmc-2018-0252
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      5d
      A survey of the role of nitrile groups in protein-ligand interactions
      Wang, Yuanxun; Du, Yunfei; Huang, Niu
      Future Medicinal Chemistry (2018), 10 (23), 2713-2728CODEN: FMCUA7; ISSN:1756-8919. (Future Science Ltd.)
      In classical medicinal chem., nitrile groups were commonly considered as bioisosteres of carbonyl, hydroxyl and carboxyl groups, as well as halogen atoms. However, there is a lack of in-depth understanding about the structural and energetic characteristics of nitrile groups in protein-ligand interactions. Here, we have surveyed the Protein Data Bank and ChEMBL databases with the goal of characterizing such protein-ligand interactions for nitrile-contg. compds. We discuss the versatile roles of nitrile groups in improving binding affinities, and give special attention to examples of displacing and mimicking binding-site waters by nitrile groups. We expect that this review article will further inspire medicinal chemists to exploit nitrile groups rationally in structure-based drug design.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXisFWrt7nE&md5=0317a874050467a6f60b5134aa909d8f

      (e) Cramer, J.; Sager, C. P.; Ernst, B. Hydroxyl groups in synthetic and natural-product-derived therapeutics: a perspective on a common functional group. J. Med. Chem. 2019, 62, 8915– 8930,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.jmedchem.9b00179
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      5e
      Hydroxyl Groups in Synthetic and Natural-Product-Derived Therapeutics: A Perspective on a Common Functional Group
      Cramer, Jonathan; Sager, Christoph P.; Ernst, Beat
      Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2019), 62 (20), 8915-8930CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. By forming extended hydrogen bond networks, the contribution of hydroxyl groups to affinity can reach several orders of magnitude. However, because of the high directionality of their interactions, a maximal affinity gain can only be achieved when the ligand scaffold allows a perfect spatial fit with the binding site. In contrast to the broad potential of hydroxyl groups for mol. recognition is their exceptionally high desolvation penalty, which can equally reduce binding affinity. As a consequence, alcs. are rarely present in synthetic drugs, but predominantly found in therapeutics derived directly or inspired from natural products, which were shaped under evolutionary pressure. In this perspective, advantages as well as drawbacks influencing the use of OH groups in medicinal chem. are discussed and illustrated with four exemplary case studies. Addnl., guidelines for drug design are derived from common features found in existing therapeutics.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXptlOjsLY%253D&md5=5fff184a72d160ae211d4bc3d8dfba47
    6. 6
      (a) Johnson, T. W.; Gallego, R. A.; Edwards, M. P. Lipophilic efficiency as an important metric in drug design. J. Med. Chem. 2018, 61, 6401– 6420,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.jmedchem.8b00077
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      6a
      Lipophilic Efficiency as an Important Metric in Drug Design
      Johnson, Ted W.; Gallego, Rebecca A.; Edwards, Martin P.
      Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2018), 61 (15), 6401-6420CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. Lipophilic efficiency (LipE) is an important metric that has been increasingly applied in drug discovery medicinal chem. lead optimization programs. In this perspective, using literature drug discovery examples, we discuss the concept of rigorously applying LipE to guide medicinal chem. lead optimization toward drug candidates with potential for superior in vivo efficacy and safety, esp. when guided by physiochem. property-based optimization (PPBO). Also highlighted are examples of small structural modifications such as addn. of single atoms, small functional groups, and cyclizations that produce large increases in LipE. Understanding the factors that may contribute to LipE changes through anal. of ligand-protein crystal structures and using structure-based drug design (SBDD) to increase LipE by design is also discussed. Herein we advocate for use of LipE anal. coupled with PPBO and SBDD as an efficient mechanism for drug design.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXmsVahsbg%253D&md5=29f38880914fa75c33be3a640ace4309
      .
      (b) Young, R. J.; Leeson, P. D. Mapping the efficiency and physicochemical trajectories of successful optimizations. J. Med. Chem. 2018, 61, 6421– 6467,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.jmedchem.8b00180
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      6b
      Mapping the Efficiency and Physicochemical Trajectories of Successful Optimizations
      Young, Robert J.; Leeson, Paul D.
      Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2018), 61 (15), 6421-6467CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
      The practices and tactics employed in successful optimizations are examd., judged from the trajectories of ligand efficiency and property evolution. A wide range of targets is analyzed, encompassing a variety of hit finding methods (HTS, fragments, encoded library technol.) and types of mols., including those beyond the rule of five. The wider employment of efficiency metrics and lipophilicity control is evident in contemporary practice and the impact on quality demonstrable. What is clear is that while targets are different, successful mols. are almost invariably among the most efficient for their target, even at the extremes. Trajectory mapping, based on principles rather than rules, is useful in assessing quality and progress in optimizations while benchmarking against competitors and assessing property-dependent risks.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXntVCmu7Y%253D&md5=f040ef02d161e070bb5021fde1585e66
